greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = b(2*n-1)/b(2*n) where b(n) = A195441(n-1) = denominator(Bernoulli_{n}(x) - Bernoulli_{n}).
comment: a(n) is an integer for all n, a(n) is odd if n is not a power of 2, a(2^k)=2 for all k>=1, a(n)=1 infinitely often, and a(n)=p infinitely often for every prime p. See Cor. 2 and Cor. 3 in "The denominators of power sums of arithmetic progressions". See also "Power-sum denominators".
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
B. C. Kellner, On a product of certain primes, arXiv:1705.04303 [math.NT] 2017; J. Number Theory, 179 (2017), 126-141.
B. C. Kellner and J. Sondow, Power-sum denominators, arXiv:1705.03857 [math.NT], 2017; Amer. Math. Monthly, 124 (2017), 695-709.
Bernd C. Kellner and Jonathan Sondow, The denominators of power sums of arithmetic progressions, arXiv:1705.05331 [math.NT] 2017; Integers, 18 (2018), article A95.
mathematica: b[n_] := Denominator[ Together[ BernoulliB[n, x] - BernoulliB[n]]]; Table[
results.author: Bernd C. Kellner and _Jonathan Sondow_, May 12 2017
